subject: Why do the mods allow the BBBY general to stay up?
gestalt_summary: The thread is a fierce battleground between deeply entrenched believers in a complex, multi-entity merger theory for BBBY, who anticipate a massive short squeeze, and skeptics who dismiss these theories as delusional and financially ruinous for retail investors. It exemplifies the psychological warfare and tribalism common in meme stock communities on 4chan, where detailed, often obscure, financial arguments are pitted against conventional market realities, often accompanied by aggressive personal attacks and accusations of "shilling."
top_quote:
You seem terribly upset. So much so that you're lying in your crying thread to try to scare away lurkers from buying winning lottery tickets. 
>How many years until you admit that you were wrong? 
IRC Section 382 requires a 3 year testing period when there is more than a 50% change in ownership among shareholders who own more than 5%. Essentially the acquirer must wait 3 years after such a change in control before merging otherwise there will be perpetual annual limits to NOL use.
>All you've managed to find are
Incontrovertible evidence of a merger due to the way the global settlement system for the trading of financial instruments is handled, yes.
>And let's face it, it's not even you that's doing any searching
That's where you're wrong, kiddo.
>It's pathetic. You're delusional. Move on.
Imagine being this upset over something that doesn't affect you. Unless, of course, it does affect you. Or more specifically, your employer.
>And even if you end up being right about the shell being used 
I am. Thank you for the concession. 
>You are getting absolutely nothing. Who in the world would bother to find money to distribute it to others when they don't have to? 
Oh but they do have to. When a tax-free merger [IRC 368(a)(1)(A)] occurs, the target company’s NOLs carry over to the acquiring company; however, for a merger to be considered tax-free, at least 80% of the total consideration must be paid in the form of voting stock of the acquiring company, especially in a reverse triangle merger [IRC 368 (a)(2)(E)].
>And let's say your shares do come back by some absolutely fucking miracle, the shorts are gone. Gone. 
A short sale creates a synthetic long. All longs are legally purchased and entitled to the same consideration. The obligation to reconcile the imbalance falls on those who sold something they didn't own in the first place, which is why you are here crying about it.
image_analysis: The attached image is a YouTube thumbnail featuring a man speaking, with a text overlay that reads 'This is what mental Illness looks like in 2025,' implying that believing in BBBY's revival is a delusion.

subject: How do these solana memecoin trader "KOLs" literally all have 100% win-rates every single day for a year?
gestalt_summary: METANARRATIVE: The thread exposes the dark underbelly of hyper-volatile memecoin markets, where seemingly impossible trading success by "KOLs" is attributed to sophisticated market manipulation, money laundering, and the exploitation of a desperate retail audience through mechanisms like orchestrated pump-and-dumps and controlled "copy-trading" flows. It highlights the inherent distrust and suspicion within these unregulated crypto niches, suggesting that consistent, high-figure profits are almost certainly a result of illicit activity rather than legitimate trading skill.
top_quote: FYI: I made $400,000 on a coin, was the top PNL for it, and after I did this, I had a few hundred people copy-trading me. When I realized what was going on, I started spam selling into the copy-traders, and made about 120 SOL in a night, but the next day I woke up, almost every single copy-trader I had stopped copy-trading me, and by the end of the 2nd day, I had no more copy-traders left. So I refuse to believe Cupsey is being copy-traded by organic random people. The copy-traders he has must be the actual money launders he's working for.
